body_html: @drpngx @keveman I tried convergence on ResNet-50 and I can't determine whether the slow IDCT is markedly better than the fast one from a convergence perspective. This was with the data loading queue and preprocessing queue all set to 1 thread, and using fixed initialization seeds, so this is as much determinism as I could imagine having control over. I'd imagine the Inception results would be very similar, and if anything, smaller nets like AlexNet would be even less sensitive to decoding issues.
body_text: @drpngx @keveman I tried convergence on ResNet-50 and I can't determine whether the slow IDCT is markedly better than the fast one from a convergence perspective. This was with the data loading queue and preprocessing queue all set to 1 thread, and using fixed initialization seeds, so this is as much determinism as I could imagine having control over. I'd imagine the Inception results would be very similar, and if anything, smaller nets like AlexNet would be even less sensitive to decoding issues.
body:
@drpngx @keveman I tried convergence on ResNet-50 and I can't determine whether the slow IDCT is markedly better than the fast one from a convergence perspective. This was with the data loading queue and preprocessing queue all set to 1 thread, and using fixed initialization seeds, so this is as much determinism as I could imagine having control over. I'd imagine the Inception results would be very similar, and if anything, smaller nets like AlexNet would be even less sensitive to decoding issues.

![slow_vs_fast](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/476135/19537852/6abd3cb2-9606-11e6-8bb0-81302fdf1c2b.png)
